      "DEPENDENCIES": ["luminous highlights", "dreamy, celestial lighting", "glowing texture"]
    },
    {
      "Q": "Should the windmill’s blades be shown in motion (rotating) or remain static, and how does this choice impact the expression of emotional intensity and inner turmoil in the composition?",
      "DIMENSION": "FORM",
      "WHY": "Motion conveys dynamic energy and movement, while stillness emphasizes emotional stillness and inner turmoil — both are central to the expression theme.",
      "PRIORITY": 2,
      "ANSWER_FORMAT": "motion state (e.g., rotating or static) + emotional impact explanation",
      "DEPENDENCIES": ["emotional intensity", "inner turmoil", "swirling, organic forms"]
    },
    {
      "Q": "What texture characteristics (e.g., rough, smooth, brushed, metallic) are expected for the windmill’s wooden body and metal blades, and how do these textures interact with the impasto brushwork and surrounding soft transitions?",
      "DIMENSION": "TEXTURE",
      "WHY": "Texture differentiates earthly form from celestial softness, and must align with both Van Gogh’s expressive impasto and Ghibli’s tactile, organic surfaces.",
      "PRIORITY": 3,
      "ANSWER_FORMAT": "texture per element (e.g., rough wood, metallic edge) + interaction with brushwork",
      "DEPENDENCIES": ["impasto brushstrokes", "visible texture", "soft flowing transitions"]
    }
  ],
  "COUNT": 3,
  "NEGATIVE_CHECKS": [
    "Does the windmill lack visible impasto texture or appear flat and realistic?",
    "Are the stars missing a glow or gradient, appearing as simple dots without luminous quality?",
    "Is the windmill’s form overly static or mechanical, lacking emotional movement?",
    "Do the textures of the windmill contradict the soft, flowing transitions in the starfield?"
  ],
  "FOLLOWUP_TRIGGERS": [
    "IF LIGHTING mentions glow effect THEN ask for gradient direction or intensity range",
    "IF FORM specifies motion state THEN ask for blade rotation speed or implied motion cues",
    "IF TEXTURE references material THEN ask for brushstroke interaction or layering details"
  ]
}
